entry.title: Can I merge the schedule lines by vendor?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I would like to ask whether SAP provides any standard transaction or tool to collect and consolidate schedule line data into a single document.

Important clarification:
I am not looking for PR consolidation (e.g., ME58) or merging PRs into one PO.
What I need is specifically related to schedule lines.

Use case:

  • We often have many materials (25–50) from the same vendor.
  • Each material has its own schedule line(s), and we would like to organize all related schedule line information in one single document.
  • The reason is to avoid handling each item one-by-one and instead have one consolidated overview of all schedule lines belonging to the same supplier.

My question is:
Does SAP offer a standard way to collect/merge schedule line data into one document, or is this something that typically requires a custom solution (e.g., report, BAdI, or enhancement)?

Thank you in advance for any guidance!

entry.title: Re: SAP CAP + PostgreSQL - how to remove field from schem...
entry.content: This is a known limitation of CAP with PostgreSQL. CAP intentionally does not support destructive schema changes (dropping columns or changing column types) with schema_evolution: "auto" for PostgreSQL, as documented here: https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/guides/databases-postgres#limitations Manually altering the database is not recommended, as it can break CAP’s automatic schema evolution tracking. At the moment, CAP does not provide a supported way to safely drop columns in PostgreSQL without recreating tables.

entry.title: Clarification on Long‑Term Safety of Using Custom Wrapper Classes for Compact Styling in Fiori Apps
entry.content:
Hello, For one of our Fiori applications, we need a more compact layout (smaller font size, reduced padding/margins, tighter table rows, etc...). To achieve this while staying within SAP‑recommended guidelines, we avoided modifying standard SAP classes.  Instead, we applied custom wrapper classes such as:  

CSS

 

controller.js

These custom classes are then added only to our List Report or Object Page root elements.

Before we continue with this approach for the long term, I would like to confirm:

  1. Is this approach (using custom wrapper/root classes around standard SAP controls) fully upgrade‑safe according to SAP guidelines?
    We are not changing .sapMBtn, .sapMLabel, .sapMTitle, or other standard selectors directly — only inside our own scope classes.

  2. Does SAP recommend any alternative technique for global compact styling of standard Fiori Elements applications?

entry.title: Re: MASTER CONTRACT IN SALES CONTRACT
entry.content:
The Master Contract field in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is used to group and centrally manage multiple sales contracts under one overarching agreement. It provides a way to link related contracts for reporting, compliance, and governance purposes, but it does not replace the individual contract’s customer/material scope.

Business use of the Master Contract field are

  • Central governance: Acts as a “parent” contract that defines overarching terms and conditions (e.g., legal clauses, commercial framework).
  • Contract hierarchy: Allows you to link multiple operational sales contracts to one master agreement.
  • Simplified reporting: Enables consolidated visibility of all linked contracts for monitoring revenue, compliance, and performance.
  • Audit and compliance: Ensures that all subordinate contracts adhere to the same master

entry.title: Re: Creating a customer returns (CBAR) with reference to...
entry.content:
No additional configuration is available in Public Cloud to enable LZ → CBAR directly.  The only workaround is process‑based:

  • Use the sales order or invoice generated from the scheduling agreement as the reference for CBAR.
  • This ensures compliance with the standard cloud model.

If your business case strongly requires direct LZ → CBAR, it would need to be raised as an SAP Influence/Enhancement request, but it’s not currently part of the delivered scope.

entry.title: Re: What is the best payment interface From SAP to bank p...
entry.content:
For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (MBC) with scope item 16R is the recommended payment interface for bank integration, offering the greatest flexibility and automated integration capabilities
Solved: Bank Integration - SAP Community

Available Payment Interface Options:
- SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (16R)Cloud-based service providing secure connectivity to multiple banks with automated integration
- Bank Integration with File Interface (1EG)File-based integration for payment processing without MBCIndividual bank connectionsLow - Manual file handling

- Application Interface to Retrieve - Payment Files (2YM) API-based interface for payment file retrieval
Recommendation: SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (16R) is the best option due to its greater flexibility, faster automated integration, and comprehensive bank support, despite requiring separate licensing

See Process Navigator - SAP for Me
Solution Scenarios ->  SAP Best Practices for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

entry.title: Time Recording in SAP PS with CATS (2) -Time Recording to Network Activities and Activity Elements
entry.content:
In this blog series, Time Recording in SAP Project System using CATS, we provide scenario-based demonstrations of end-to-end processes, including

  • Time Recording for WBS element,
  • Time Recording for Network Activity/Element,
  • Time Recording for Network Header,

together with the “Project Builder” and “My Timesheet (S/4HANA / Version 4)” (F3074A), which is available as of SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01.

This is the second post in the series. In the first post, we focused on time recording to WBS elements. This post shifts the focus to Network Activities and Activity Elements, which are execution-level objects used for detailed planning, resource assignment, and capacity tracking.

Unlike WBS elements, Network Activities and Activity Elements support person assignment and worklist generation, enabling more structured and automated time recording processes. This makes them suitable for operational projects where task-level effort tracking and confirmations are essential.

Note: For prerequisite setup (e.g. HR Mini Master, Work Center, CATS Profile), please refer to the first post in this series.

Scenario B: Time Recording to Network Activities and Network Elements

This scenario demonstrates how internal labor time is recorded against network activities and their activity elements. Compared to WBS elements or network headers, network activities support detailed operational execution, including:

  • Person assignment
  • Worklist generation
  • Capacity planning
  • Confirmation and costing

While network headers and WBS elements allow manual time recording, only network activities support task assignment via worklist and workforce planning.

4.1 Project Setup

To showcase both time recording to network activity and time recording to activity elements, we created a sample project (DL-BAD.016) in Project Builder (CJ20N).

Two networks are in this project:

  1. IT & Equipment Installation (400682) contains a network activity (IT Installation) assigned directly to the network.
  2. Interior Construction (4002660) contains a network activity (Internal Labor) that is further broken down into two activity elements
    1. Drywall Work
    2. Painting & Finishing

Project DL-BAD.016

This setup allows us to compare both options side by side.

Activity elements provide further breakdown for complex tasks, enabling more granular scheduling or capacity planning.

The setup and planning steps for network activities and activity elements are similar. Both require configuration of work center, activity type, planned work, and duration (at network activity level). To avoid redundancy, we describe the planning and assignment process using the network activity example. These steps apply equally to activity elements.

During planning phase, assign Work Center to the network activity. Define Activity Type, Work, and Duration in the Internal tab. Make sure Calculation Key is set correctly (e.g., Work = Duration * Capacity). Furthermore, to allow timesheet data to be transferred to confirmations (in this example unit is Hours), ensure the Control Key used for internal processing (e.g. PS01) allows confirmation (e.g Comfirmation required).

When using both network activities and elements for planning, you should only assign resources on either activity or element level. In case resources are assigned to both, this will result in double planning.

4.2 Person Assignment and Worklist Generation

After the creation of the activity with planned work, we can assign this activity to an employee. Two prerequisites are needed to enable capacity planning and automatic worklist generation for network activities:

  1. In the network header, the Capacity Requirement indicator must be active.
  2. In CATS Entry Profile, worklist is enabled and From resource plng checkbox is ticked.

To assign personal to a network activity (or activity element), you can either do it via the network activity’s Person Assignment tab or use the Workforce Planning app (transaction CMP2) for more detailed capacity planning. Note that to use the Workforce Planning app for planning, you need to define a Workforce Planning Profile in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> Project System -> Resources -> Define Profiles for Workforce Planning.

Capacity planning for a network activity in Project Builder Person Assignment tab

In Person Assignment tab, if the checkbox Only from w/p is checked, you can only select human resources that are assigned to the work center; if not, you can select from all the available HR resources (see 2.2). After the planning, release the project so assignments are visible in the employee’s worklist (worklist must be enabled in CATS Data Entry Profile, see 2.5).

View capacity planning with predefined Workforce Planning Profile in the Workforce Planning app (1)

View capacity planning in the Workforce Planning app (2)

4.3 Time Recording to Network Activities

In the My Timesheet Fiori app, switch to the correct CATS Profile (see 2.4) that supports worklist (if needed). In Time Entry editing mode, open the value help dialog on a specific date and go to the worklist tab. You will see the worklist generated from the network activity, showing the corresponding network ID and name.

Select time entry pop-up

Worklist generated from network activity: IT Installation Internal Labor

Optionally, you can save the selected worklist entry (currently displayed as Worklist) as an assignment for readability and reusability. First, click on the Edit button; in the pop-up, click on the Save as Assignment and give it an appropriate name.

Selected entry displayed as Worklist

Save the worklist entry as an assignment

With the entry selected, enter the number of hours and check the entry. If the check is successful, click on Submit. If an approval workflow is active (defined in CATS Data Entry Profile, see 2.4), the time must be approved before transfer.

Although the time is recorded, the cost is not yet posted. To transfer the booking to Project System (PS) and Controlling (CO), use program RCATSTPS in SE38 or transaction CAT5. The transfer generates network confirmations in PS, and the hours and costs become actuals on the network activity. This report can be scheduled to run automatically as a background job. 

Recorded time entry

Transfer recorded time to the Project System

Time transferred and confirmation generated

Confirmation for network activity IT Installation Internal Labor (4002682 0010)

4.4 View Actual Work and Posted Cost

Navigate to the Project Builder Person assignment tab, we can see the Capacity Requirement is reduced from 24 to 16 hours, because 8 hours of work is performed and transferred to the Project System (PS).

The remaining work is calculated

In the Dates tab, the actual has been updated, and 8 hours of work are logged.

In Dates tab, actual work is updated

You can review costs, e.g., by using the Project System Infosystem or the Project Cost Fiori apps. In this example, we can view the cost using the following apps:

  • CJI3N – Display Actual Line Items for WBS.
  • S_ALR_87013532– plan/actual/variance overview in SAP Project System.

Actual cost posted fo­­r network activity (CJI3N)

Plan/Actual/Variance for the project DL-BAD.016 (S_ALR_87013532)

A more detailed overview of the planned/actual work based on the project structure

By performing the same steps on activity elements, we can see the same actual cost posted for network Interior Construction.

Confirmation for activity element Drywall Work (4002681 0010 0020)

Plan/Actual/Variance for the project DL-BAD.016 (S_ALR_87013532)

I'm encountering this bug related to the ABAP Cross Trace and I couldn't find a patch. I have opened a case with SAP Support and waiting for their help. I'm posting here if someone can help, just in case. I'll do an update as soon as I get some news from SAP.

My system is S/4HANA 2023 FPS 01 ON-PREMISE.

The ABAP Cross Trace does a short dump of the recorded Fiori App when doing the steps below:

  1. I log in the system XXX, with user XXXXXXXX, both in Eclipse ADT 2025-09 and in Fiori LaunchPad.
  2. I start the Fiori App F0798 (Create Billing Documents) and filter by the sales order 6100000202.
  3. In Eclipse ADT, I create an ABAP Cross Trace configuration with default values + option "ABAP BAdIs".
  4. In the Fiori App F0798, I select the Sales Order 6100000202 and I click "Create Invoice Document".
  5. There's an error message in the Fiori App ("Sorry, a technical error occurred. Please try again later."), three short dumps were generated and six ABAP traces were recorded.

If I deactivate the ABAP Cross Trace, the Fiori App doesn't fail.

Note that the ABAP Cross Trace works for this Fiori App for some other actions (like navigating, no business object update).

      /IWFND/CL_SODATA_HTTP_HANDLER=>IF_HTTP_EXTENSION~HANDLE_REQUEST
    3 METHOD       CL_HTTP_SERVER================CP    CL_HTTP_SERVER================CM00D   814
      CL_HTTP_SERVER=>EXECUTE_REQUEST
    2 FUNCTION     SAPLHTTP_RUNTIME                    LHTTP_RUNTIMEU02                     1627
      HTTP_DISPATCH_REQUEST
    1 MODULE (PBO) SAPMHTTP                            SAPMHTTP                               12
      %_HTTP_START

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: how to settle the costs from parent WBS (Level 1) not...
entry.content:
If you want Level 2 WBS to act only as a cost collector and settlement to happen from Level 1 WBS, try the below options

Do not maintain settlement rules on Level 2 WBS. Instead, assign settlement rules only to Level 1 WBS. But since costs are posted to Level 2, you need a way to “push” them up.

Use “Automatic Account Assignment” or “Cost Roll‑Up”. In Project Profile, you can set “Acct assignment element = No” for Level 2 WBS. This way, costs posted to Level 2 will automatically roll up to Level 1 (the first account‑assigned WBS in the hierarchy). Then settlement happens only from Level 1.

entry.title: Generating and Integrating Automated Predictive Library (APL) Forecasts in a Seamless Planning Model
entry.content:
Introduction 

SAP Analytics Cloud has always been the one solution for BI, planning and predictive analytics. As such, it has powerful built-in capabilities for regression, classification and time-series forecasting. You know them as Predictive Scenarios and many of you have used them to support their planning processes. Our predictive scenarios are perfect for business users: they choose the best available algorithm for your data and explain the results while maintaining the semantics of the model throughout the process (e.g., hierarchies). With SAP Business Data Cloud and seamless planning, data scientists on the other hand can now leverage HANA’s predictive Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) and Automated Predictive Library (APL) directly on the HANA database of SAP Datasphere and nicely integrate the results into planning processes. This lets them tweak predictive models by picking and choosing the algorithm of their choice and use code instead of a UI. SAP BDC would also allow them to share data with SAP Databricks or another Databricks instance using data products if this was their preferred environment. 

This blogpost was created with @marc_daniau, a development expert for our predictive engine. We want to demonstrate the usage of HANA APL in combination with a seamless planning model and live versions. We do this using a straight-forward prediction based on actual data.  

 

High-level overview 

This is what we are working with: 

In SAP Analytics Cloud, we have a planning model deployed to an SAP Datasphere space. That makes it a seamless planning model which means that its data is not stored on the SAP Analytics Cloud database but only on the SAP Datasphere database.  

In the SAP Datasphere space, we find the planning model data and a table with actuals. We are not using an SAP BDC data product, but you surely could! 

We create our prediction directly on the underlying HANA Cloud database of SAP Datasphere. We created a DB user to access the database. There, we consume the actuals, create a stored procedure which we can trigger via a task chain, and surface the result in a view in the space. This fact data can then be added to the seamless planning model as a live version.  

 

Step-by-step 

1. Seamless planning model 

We do not cover the full creation and set-up of the model. Let’s just check out its key characteristics:  

  • It is a seamless planning model, deployed to the space Sales Planning Demo 
  • Its fact table is exposed in the SAP Datasphere space (actually, this is not decisive for the use case described here but could be useful if you want to add budget data as influence for your predictive model, for instance) 
  •  We want to create a forecast version and predict the measure SALES_REVENUE along the product and region dimension 

2. SAP Datasphere space

Again, we do not look at the creation of the space and all its artefacts. The following Actuals view is key as we extrapolate our forecast based on this data: 

  • Measures and attributes nicely match the planning model structure (which is handy for our simple demo scenario J) 
  • We excluded columns that we do not need in a projection 
  • We filtered on date as we do not want to use the entire history 

3. Setting up database access 

We are now ready to learn how to create the forecast on the HANA database. First of all, we need to set up database access.  

  • Prerequisite: Enable the SAP HANA Cloud Script Server on Your SAP Datasphere Tenant 
  • Navigate to Space Management, find your space and Edit.  
  • Navigate to Database Access and create a new user 
     
  • Name your user and make the needed settings as highlighted. Your user’s name will be a concatenation of your space name, ‘#’ and the suffix you provide here. 
     
  • Mark your user and open the database explorer. The password can be retrieved in the details of the user (information symbol).  

4. Database explorer 

Let’s first have an overview of what we are creating in the database explorer: 

 

  • We create a view that consumes the actual data from our space schema. Note the following: 
  • We concatenate Product and Region to one Entity column that we will use to segment our prediction. As we work directly on flat fact tables/views, we do not have the luxury of keeping all semantics as we have it in the SAP Analytics Cloud predictive scenarios.  

 

CREATE VIEW "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_SERIES_IN" ( "Entity", "Date", "SalesRevenue" ) AS (select   
  "Product" || '|' || "Regions" as "Entity", "Date", "SalesRevenue" 
 from  
  SALES_PLANNING_DEMO."V_Actual_Sales_Data" 
 order by 1, 2)

  • We now create the prediction task as a stored procedure.  
create procedure "APL_FORECAST_TASK" 
as BEGIN
    declare header "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.FUNCTION_HEADER";
    declare config "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.OPERATION_CONFIG_DETAILED";
	declare var_desc "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.VARIABLE_DESC_OID";   
    declare var_role "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.VARIABLE_ROLES_WITH_COMPOSITES_OID";    
    declare apl_log   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.OPERATION_LOG";      
    declare apl_sum   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.SUMMARY";   
    declare apl_indic   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.INDICATORS";   	
    declare apl_metr "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_METRIC_OID";
    declare apl_prop "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_PROPERTY_OID";      

    truncate table "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_SERIES_OUT";
    truncate table "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY";
    truncate table "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_STATUS";
	
    :header.insert(('Oid', 'DSP APL'));
    :header.insert(('LogLevel', '2'));
    :header.insert(('MaxTasks', '4'));  --  PARALLEL TASKS

    :config.insert(('APL/SegmentColumnName', 'Entity',null)); 
    :config.insert(('APL/Horizon', '12',null));
    :config.insert(('APL/TimePointColumnName', 'Date',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/ForcePositiveForecast', 'true',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/DecomposeInfluencers', 'true',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/ApplyExtraMode', 'First Forecast with Stable Components and Residues and Error Bars',null));
	
    :var_role.insert(('Date', 'input', null, null, null));
    :var_role.insert(('SalesRevenue', 'target', null, null, null));
		
    "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::FORECAST_AND_DEBRIEF" (
	:header, :config, :var_desc, :var_role, 
	'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER', 'APL_SERIES_IN', 
	'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER', 'APL_SERIES_OUT', apl_log, apl_sum, apl_indic, apl_metr, apl_prop);

    insert into "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY" 
    select "Oid" as "Entity", "MAE", "MAPE"
    from "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.debrief.report::TimeSeries_Performance" (:apl_prop, :apl_metr)
    where "Partition" = 'Validation';
	
	insert into "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_STATUS" 
    select "OID" as "Entity", "VALUE" as "Task Status"
	from :apl_sum 
	where key = 'AplTaskStatus';
END

For our demo scenario we use the default APL forecasting method that automatically tries different hypotheses for trend, cycles and fluctuations, and eventually selects the combination that gives the best accuracy. For a faster processing on many segments, an option is to force the Exponential Smoothing method by adding to the procedure this line of code below: 

:config.insert(('APL/ForecastMethod','ExponentialSmoothing',null));

This is the code to prepare the target tables of the procedure: 

drop table APL_SERIES_OUT;
create table APL_SERIES_OUT (
 "Entity"  nvarchar(180),
 "Date" 	DATE,
 "SalesRevenue" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Trend" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Cycles" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1_lowerlimit_95%" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1_upperlimit_95%" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1ExtraPreds" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Fluctuations" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Residues" DOUBLE
);

 

drop table APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY;
create table APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY (
 "Entity"  nvarchar(180),
 "MAE" DOUBLE,
 "MAPE" DOUBLE
);

 

drop table APL_FORECAST_STATUS;
create table APL_FORECAST_STATUS (
 "Entity"  nvarchar(180),
 "Task Status" nvarchar(180)
);
  • You can trigger this procedure manually using the command below: 
call "APL_FORECAST_TASK" ;

However, in the next chapter, we will also create a task chain in SAP Datasphere to trigger it which can be embedded in real workflows.  

  • You see we generate and write data into three different tables: 
  • The prediction result goes into our results table called APL_SERIES_OUT. This is the data that we want for our seamless planning model. The table has the concatenated entity, date and the predicted revenue. It also comes with upper and lower limit predictions (95%) as well as with fluctuations, extra predictions etc.  
     
  • Optionally, we create the table APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY to store the MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error MAE (Mean Absolute Error) per entity. You could filter on the entities you are interested in, the best/worst entities etc. or you could get the MSE (Mean Squared Error) or RMSE (Root Mean Absolute Squared Error) as well.  

  • Optionally, we create the table APL_FORECAST_STATUS where we log the prediction status per entity. All our entities were successful.  

 

5. Task chain 

Stored procedures can be executed via task chains. As such, you can execute them from the SAP Datasphere UI, schedule them or trigger them via external API. Check out the task chain documentation to learn more about prerequisites such as required roles. Soon, you should be able to trigger this API via multi actions in SAP Analytics Cloud as well.  

We must allow the execution of the stored procedure via the SAP Datasphere UI including the creation and deletion of data in the database user schema:  

CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" ( 
             OPERATION => 'GRANT',  
             PRIVILEGE => 'INSERT',  
             SCHEMA_NAME => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER',  
             OBJECT_NAME => '',  
             SPACE_ID => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO');

              

CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" ( 
             OPERATION => 'GRANT',  
             PRIVILEGE => 'DELETE',  
             SCHEMA_NAME => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER',  
             OBJECT_NAME => '',  
             SPACE_ID => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO');

 

CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" ( 
             OPERATION => 'GRANT',  
             PRIVILEGE => 'EXECUTE',  
             SCHEMA_NAME => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER',  
             OBJECT_NAME => '',  
             SPACE_ID => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO');

Setting up task chains is simple. To add a stored procedures, you select Others and browse through the available procedures that are available for your space. Then you drag the procedure on to the canvas to add it as a task.    

You can add replication flows, transformation flows, intelligent lookups etc. to your task chains. By that, you could for instance first refresh actuals and get them into shape so you can use them for your prediction. Or, you add an email notification task to receive updates after the execution of the task chain (I did that in the example below).  

6. Consuming results in the SAP Datasphere space 

Now that we have the predictive logic to calculate and we can execute it via the SAP Datasphere UI, we of course need to consume the forecast data in the planning model. To do that, we first need the results in the SAP Datasphere space. We create a view on top of the results table. We used a graphical view but depending on your preferences and skills, you may use an SQL view instead.  

  • Pull the results table from the DB user schema in the Sources tab. 

  • Add a calculation node to split the Entity column into regions and products again. Create two calculated columns (Product and Region) and use string functions.  The functions SUBSTR_BEFORE() and SUBSTR_AFTER() can be used to split a string using the first occurence of a specified pattern (in our case '|'  as the format of our Entity column is Product|Region). 

 Expression to derive product:

SUBSTR_BEFORE(Entity,'|')

Expression to derive region:

SUBSTR_AFTER(Entity,'|')
  •  Join the standard time dimension with day granularity to derive the calendar month from the date. Standard time tables and dimensions can be generated in Space Management (link).  

  • Add a projection and only keep the columns you need in the planning model. 
    • Calendar Month 
    • SalesRevenue 
    • Product 
    • Region 
  • Make sure to expose the view for consumption and select Fact as the Semantic Usage Type.  
  • Name the view and deploy.  

7. Adding the forecast result as live version in the seamless planning model 

We now move to SAP Analytics Cloud and add the forecast result to the seamless planning model as a live version.  

  • Connect external data source. 

  • Create a version to map the data into (or use an existing un-used version). 
  • Select the view. 
  • Map the columns. 
     
  • Preview the data. You see that we have a live connection to the forecast results in SAP Datasphere. So every time that the forecast is updated, it will be reflected in the planning model in real time! 

 

What (else) can/could you do with it?  

In SAP Analytics Cloud:  

  • You can display the live version data in the model data foundation and in tables, charts, etc. in stories. 
  • You can reference the live version data in model and story calculations as well as data actions (incl. advanced formulas). 
  • You cannot write back into the referenced views (or rather their underlying tables). But, you can copy the live version data into planning versions via copy/paste in the table, data actions and version management. 

In SAP Datasphere: 

  • You can of course leverage the forecast result in your views and analytic models and compare it to actuals, budgets, etc.  
  • You can run further transformations and calculations and report on the results or use them in planning.  
  • … 

 

Which new features can improve the workflow in the future? 

We are working on a couple of features that can make this scenario even better: 

  • Push data from SAP Datasphere into the seamless planning model via task chains:  
    Live versions are awesome. But, sometimes you want to use the prediction as a proposal and then edit it. You could copy the live version data into an editable version easily (see above) but with a push of data into the planning model, you could directly bring the data into an editable forecast version. That push could be nicely added to the same task chain that triggers the APL procedure. 
  • Trigger task chains from SAP Analytics Cloud:
    Task chains shall soon offer a public API for triggering task chain runs from outside of SAP Datasphere.
    We are getting ready on the SAP Analytics Cloud side to let you call this API via API steps in multi actions. With that, you could trigger the stored procedures from SAP Analytics Cloud.  
    Some day, we may have dedicated task chain steps in multi actions to ease this cross-orchestration. We also want to enable cross-orchestration in the opposite direction.  

 

Conclusion 

In this blogpost, Marc and I demonstrated how to integrate predictive forecast results from SAP HANA APL in a seamless planning model. We combined the power of SAP Datasphere, SAP HANA and SAP Analytics Cloud to achieve that in a quite straight-forward architecture. You could achieve more complex scenarios, use PAL instead to tweak your prediction more etc. Or you could use data products from SAP BDC to get you started even quicker.  

We are looking forward to the future enhancements that shall improve such workflows and the overall integration of planning into SAP BDC! 

 

Learn More 

  • Seamless Planning - Product FAQ 
  • Seamless Planning – Live Versions 
  • SAP HANA Automated Predictive Library (APL) 
  • SAP HANA Predictive Analysis Library (PAL)  
  • SAP Analytics Cloud Predictive Scenarios

entry.title: Using SAP Trademark/Screenshot and own videos "using SAP products" to create training content

Dear team,

 

my company plans to craete a video training course for people to loarn ABAP develpment using the SAP BTP ABAP environment and ABAP Development tools.

entry.title: Re: Billing document not showing in e-document cockpit fo...
entry.content: For information, eDocuments are generated based on the issuing company code’s country, not the customer’s country. Since your invoice was posted in company code India, only the India eDocument scenario applies. If you require Swiss eDocuments, you must use a Swiss company code and activate the Switzerland scenario as per SAP Note 3164838. Please also check other related SAP notes like 3203653 and 3203654.

entry.title: Re: A Wish for CLI-Based ABAP
entry.content:
Hi Mattias

It is interesting but also so surreal for me to see "CLI" and "modern" put together.

I have been a programmer for 40 years and when I started out as assembly, fortran, cobol and C (not c++ or c# just c) there was only cli terminals - no GUI. I was a vi editor champ and I remember the happiness of mastering vi - being one of the geeks. 

Even if I was a vi editor champ, I realized in the mid-nineties that GUI based was better and so did 96% of all developers at that time. The rest 4% was considered to bee the hardcore geeks.

My opinion has not changed. I still preferer gui based whenever it make sense.

For example I find it a waste of my limited brain capacity to remember eml commands and syntax just to write eml code to define a new table when I could just fill a few fields in SE11. I know SE11 is not self-explanatory but the gui kind of guide my brain to focus on what are important  decisions for tabel creation.

So, did i allow the designer of the gui to make important decisions about what my brain shall focus on. Yes, and I'm happy with that. I can still create a table differently in the rare occasions when a specials requirement occur. 

And I feel the same about change management. I totally prefer SAP version management and the elegant and simple TMS / CTMS over GIT.

So good luck with having our CLI based ABAP but please don't destroy my preferred tools in the process.

Best regards 
Thomas Madsen Nielsen

entry.title: Use SAP Integration Suite to connect SAP and AWS services
entry.content:
Bridging the gap between SAP and 3rd party systems 

Everyone already knows that SAP Integration Suite is the election tool to connect your SAP services. But did you know that it is also your tool to integrate Everything, Everywhere, All in One Place? (yes, almost like the Oscar award winning movie 🏆)

Use SAP Integration Suite to connect SAP and AWS services is a new official SAP Discovery Center Mission that focus on showcasing how easy it is to integrate not only SAP systems but also non-SAP systems using SAP Integration Suite. 

For this mission, we decided to use the AWS platform as the example of third-party cloud services provider, but the same rational with this set of best practices and capabilities can be used to integrate with other cloud providers. By following the cards provided in the mission, you will see step-by-step how you can start to integrate an application developed with SAP BTP development tools with AWS services, such as S3 for image storage and Rekognition for image identification.
You can even use a SAP BTP Trial account to perform the SAP BTP parts of the mission, even though you will always still require also an AWS account to connect with the S3 and Rekognition services (and IAM for user and roles management on the AWS side). Either if you are a technical user or more of a business user interested in rapid application development, cloud integration strategies and/or AI-powered business solution, this mission is for you!

The following architecture shows the big picture of what the final result of the mission should look like, seamlessly combining the best of both SAP BTP and AWS platforms:

 

Use Case Description

The use case followed trough out the mission focuses in enabling a Supplier to donate surplus food ingredients through an AI-powered mobile and web application built using SAP Build Apps, a low-code/no-code solution within SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), seamlessly integrated with AWS capabilities for storage and artificial intelligence–based image recognition. For the integration part, you will leverage and combine different integration capabilities that are part of the SAP Integration Suite. The intended outcome of the use case is to minimize food waste while simplifying the donation process and facilitating redistribution to organizations in need.

Solution Components:

  • SAP Build Apps: The low-code/no-code application development service used to create the application (frontend and logic) where the Supplier can donate the surplus ingredients by taking or uploading photos 
  • SAP Integration Suite: The secure and centralized integration management service for all your integrations, making them easier to manage, monitor and troubleshoot
  • Amazon S3: The Amazon service for simplified and cost-effective image storage capabilities
  • Amazon Rekognition: The Amazon service for AI-powered identification and categorization, in this case used to identify the ingredients in the images taken or uploaded from the application to a S3 bucket

The Use Case Flow:

  1. A Supplier captures or uploads an image of surplus ingredients through the mobile/web app (developed with SAP Build Apps)
  2. The image is securely stored in Amazon S3 via SAP Integration Suite (using Cloud Integration, Pre-built Open Connector and API Management capabilities)
  3. Also via SAP Integration Suite, the app then calls Amazon Rekognition to automatically identify and categorize the ingredient present in the image (using Cloud Integration, Custom Open Connector and API Management capabilities)
  4. The results are sent back to the app and ready for further processing

  

Learning Outcomes

By completing this Discovery Center Mission, you'll gain practical experience in:

  • Building low-code applications with SAP Build Apps
  • Configuring SAP Integration Suite for AWS connectivity
  • Implementing secure cloud-to-cloud integrations
  • Leveraging AI services for business process automation
  • Managing integration flows and monitoring capabilities

Getting Started

Once you open and start the Mission, you will see in the Project Board the different cards that will guide you step-by-step, divided in 7 columns.

Make sure you fullfill all the requirements indicated in the SET UP and PREPARE columns. After that, you can start with the EXECUTE columns. You will first explore the Open Connectors capability of SAP Integration Suite (in the Execute - OpenConnectors), followed by the Cloud Integration and API Management capabilities of SAP Integration Suite (in the Execute - Security Material and Integration Flow) and lastly you will get to visually create a simple app screen with SAP Build Apps (in Execute - Build app) .
After finishing the mission, don't forget to mark all the cards as completed and we encourage you to leave your feedback and share your experiences with the rest of the SAP Community. 

And now, for those who saw the movie Everything Everywhere All at Once, DON'T "Just be a rock" and start the mission here!  ->  SAP Discovery Center Missions - Use SAP Integration Suite to connect SAP and AWS services

entry.title: Exploring My Path in the SAP Ecosystem — And Rediscovering My Love for Sales
entry.content:
Hello Everyone.

My name is Elizabeth Ali and I am excited to be part of this SAP Learning Community. A little about me: I am a U.S. Army veteran, a project and program manager, and a creative at heart with a background in Fashion Design and Marketing. My path has been unconventional, just like me, but it has allowed me to gain so many skills, insights, strategies, resilience and adaptability along the way.

Throughout my career, I have worked in dynamic, client-facing environments, including supporting high-profile global projects within a PR and marketing agency. Those experiences strengthened my communication, relationship building and problem-solving abilities, and reminded me how much I value work that revolves around people and connection.

I am currently working toward my SAP Certified Associate in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with the Vower learning group. This journey has been energizing and inspiring. Each lesson opens my mind to new possibilities and helps me understand more about the ecosystem I am stepping into.

Recently I found myself reflecting on the roles I have held and one experience stood out. My time driving sales and working directly with clients at Lush Cosmetics was one of my favorite roles. I loved connecting with people, understanding their needs and helping them feel confident in their decisions. Sales keeps tapping me on the shoulder, so I am turning to the community for insight.

I know there are many paths and opportunities within the sales landscape of SAP and I am exploring where my strengths may naturally align. My background is full of communication, creativity, people-focused work, structure and strategic thinking. I am curious about how all of that could translate into a sales-focused direction within the SAP world.

So I would love to hear from others in this community.
Do you work in sales within the SAP ecosystem?
What part of sales are you in?
What has your path looked like?
What do you enjoy most about the sales side of SAP?

I am genuinely exploring and learning and I truly appreciate hearing real experiences from people already doing this work.

Thank you all for welcoming me. I am excited to learn, connect and grow alongside this community.

Warm regards,
Elizabeth Ali

entry.title: LEFT JOIN LATERAL In DataSphere SQL View
entry.content:
Hello,

Being original a MS SQL writer switching now to DataSphere I'm struggling with the alternavtive for a CROSS APPLY.

I've found some sample on the LEFT JOIN LATERAL, but when I use this code DS always gives errors.

SELECT FT_CURR."FROM_CURR", FT_CURR."TO_CURR"
     , DATES."DATE_SQL"
     , EXCH_DT."EXCH_RATE"
     , EXCH_PRVDT."EXCH_RATE"
  FROM (SELECT DISTINCT "FROM_CURR", "TO_CURR" FROM "EXCHANGERATES") FT_CURR
       CROSS JOIN (SELECT "DATE_SQL" FROM "CENTRAL.2VS_DS_Dates" WHERE "YEAR" = 2025) DATES
       LEFT OUTER JOIN "EXCHANGERATES" EXCH_DT ON EXCH_DT."FROM_CURR" = FT_CURR."FROM_CURR"
                                              AND EXCH_DT."TO_CURR" = FT_CURR."TO_CURR"
                                              AND EXCH_DT."EXCH_DATE" = DATES."DATE_SQL"
       LEFT JOIN LATERAL (SELECT "FROM_CURR", "TO_CURR", "EXCH_DATE", "EXCH_RATE"
                            FROM "EXCHANGERATES"
                           WHERE "FROM_CURR" = "FT_CURR"."FROM_CURR"
                             AND "TO_CURR" = "FT_CURR"."TO_CURR"
                             AND "EXCH_DATE" < "DATES"."DATE_SQL"
                           ORDER BY "EXCH_DATE" DESC
                           LIMIT 1) EXCH_PRVDT ON EXCH_PRVDT."FROM_CURR" = FT_CURR."FROM_CURR"
                                              AND EXCH_PRVDT."TO_CURR" = FT_CURR."TO_CURR"
                                              AND EXCH_PRVDT."EXCH_DATE" < "DATES"."DATE_SQL"

First error is ‘SELECT’ is a reserved word - write ‘![SELECT]’ instead if you want to use it as name

So I'm not sure DS allows this LATERAL, and if not, what would be an alternative ?

entry.title: Re: 999 – The Number of the BSEG
entry.content:
Dear Jitka,

yes, this is a known issue. You define PAOBJNR as "additional document splitting characteristic for controlling" in order to split cash discount items (PAOBJNR-wise) in the payment documents according to the invoices, but then (during the payment) you'll quite easily run into the 999 issue on BSEG...
There's two aspects I want to share:
1) As you correctly assumed, during an F-28 or F-53 payment, no standard summarization code (BAdi or OBCY/OBCYX) will be processed, this holds true for any FB01-like postings. So I could point you to the corresponding payment FIORI apps Clear Incoming Payments or Clear Outgoing Payments instead, where technically the summarization code is at least available. And in fact, in the Public Cloud edition we enhanced the summarization so that for these FIORI apps, these cash discount (and exchange rate differences) items will be automatically summarized on BSEG; problem solved in the Public Cloud..
2) Since I assume we're talking about Private Cloud or On Premise in your case: we did develop an alternative approach already many years ago for this special case (many cash discount items in payments due to PAOBJNR split): please have a look at pilot note 2634485. 

Kind regards,
Stefan

entry.title: Re: Cannot change Revenue Recognition Key to SPFCSC for C...
entry.content: You cannot freely switch a revenue recognition key once postings or revenue recognition runs have occurred. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, the key must be set correctly at the start of the project/contract item. If you need to move from SPFC to SPFCSC, the supported approach is to create a new project/contract item with the correct key rather than changing it mid‑stream.

entry.title: Re: Standard Table for Listing InfoObjects with Attribute and Text Master Data
entry.content: There is no single Table where in both Attribute and Text master data can be found out with a list of all InfoObjects. However, you can search the individual InfoObjects using the SE11 -> "/BIC/T*" for Text & "/BIC/P*" for Attribute table.

entry.title: Re: Working day
entry.content:
There is no implemented feature which allows to compute a rating event on the fifth working day of each month.

Nevertheless, you can use a daily event in order to implement your needs.
For example, you can count the number of working days by incrementing a counter day after day. As soon as the counter is equal to 5, generate a BIT. Else reach a free component. And a monthly event reset the counter at the end of month.

Regards,

Eric F.

entry.title: Re: F0770 Payment run logs can only be viewed for 6 month...
entry.content:
No, it cannot be changed in Public Cloud. Unlike on‑premise, where you could adjust archiving or retention settings, Public Cloud follows a fit‑to‑standard approach. The 6‑month limit is fixed and not configurable by customers.

If you need to keep logs longer than 6 months, export the logs regularly. Use the Download or Export to excel option in the F0770 app. Store them in your own archive (SharePoint, OneDrive, or corporate repository).

Leverage CDS views / reporting. Use Payment Run analytical CDS views to extract payment run data into reports. Schedule regular extraction jobs to preserve historical data.

entry.title: Re: Can I merge the schedule lines by vendor?
entry.content:
SAP does not provide a standard transaction to merge or consolidate schedule line data into a single document. The system keeps schedule lines tied to their individual purchase orders or scheduling agreements. If you want a consolidated overview of all schedule lines for a vendor, this typically requires a custom report, CDS view, or enhancement rather than standard functionality

Why because, Schedule lines are designed to reflect delivery dates and quantities at the item level in purchase orders or scheduling agreements. SAP standard tools like ME58, ME59, or ME2x reports focus on PR → PO consolidation or PO monitoring, not on merging schedule lines into one document. The system intentionally keeps schedule lines separate to preserve logistics accuracy (each line has its own delivery date, quantity, and confirmation).

entry.title: Re: Control for no transactions until Cost Estimate is Run
entry.content:
SAP does not provide a hard “system lock” that prevents postings (like Goods Receipt, GI, billing) until a cost estimate is run. The standard cost estimate (CK40N, CK11N) is primarily used for valuation and variance analysis. Even if no cost estimate exists, you can still post GRs, GIs, or billing documents — they will use moving average price or last purchase price for valuation.

Having said that, the recommended Best Practice approach would be

  • Run and release cost estimates before period start (mandatory step in closing cycle).
  • Use custom enhancement (BAdI/User Exit) if you want a hard block on GR or billing until cost estimate exists.
  • Alternatively, enforce through authorization/workflow that logistics postings are not allowed until costing team confirms release.

entry.title: Why IAS Is Essential for Enterprise DIV Implementations (Part 1)
entry.content:
This is Part 1 of a three-part series on setting up SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication (IAS) with the BTP service Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV). It lays the foundation by explaining what IAS is and why it is a core building block for enterprise-grade DIV implementations.

 

Introduction

Consider a scenario where a global automotive manufacturer has decided to implement SAP’s Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) solution to enable secure, privacy-preserving digital identity management across its supply chain. The company needs to issue verifiable credentials to suppliers, partners, and employees while maintaining full control over the authentication infrastructure.

However, there’s a critical requirement: the organization wants to use its own corporate identity system rather than creating and managing separate user accounts in SAP. Employees and suppliers should authenticate using their existing corporate credentials, such as those from the manufacturer’s domain or a gearbox supplier’s identity provider, not additional SAP-specific identities.

Additionally, granular access control is essential. The manufacturer needs to define which users can access specific digital wallets and which administrators have the authority to provision and manage these wallets across different business units and partner organizations. This is where SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication (IAS) becomes indispensable.

 

What is IAS?

IAS is a cloud-based identity management solution that serves as a central authentication and single sign-on (SSO) hub for SAP and non-SAP applications.

Core Capabilities

  • Single Sign-On (SSO): Users authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without repeated logins.
  • Identity Federation: IAS can integrate with existing corporate identity providers (like Microsoft Azure AD, Google Workspace, etc.) through standards like SAML 2.0 and OpenID Connect (OIDC). This avoids duplicate user accounts.
  • Fine-Grained Access Control: Users can be assigned access to specific applications or resources—critical for multi-tenant DIV wallet scenarios.
  • Centralized User Lifecycle Management: Manage users, groups, authentication policies, and access rights consistently across systems.

 

Why Use IAS with DIV?

While DIV can technically operate without IAS, enterprise deployments strongly benefit from it. IAS addresses three core challenges: identity reuse, access control, and security.

1. Reusing Existing Corporate Identities

Most organizations already operate mature identity systems. IAS allows DIV to integrate seamlessly by:

  • Federating with corporate and partner identity providers
  • Eliminating DIV-specific user accounts
  • Simplifying onboarding and offboarding: disabling a corporate account automatically revokes DIV access

This ensures users authenticate with familiar credentials while IT retains centralized control.

2. Granular Access Control in Multi-Tenant Environments

In realistic enterprise scenarios, different stakeholders require different levels of access. Consider the automotive manufacturer example: The finance department needs access to a dedicated wallet tenant for financial audit credentials. The supply chain team requires access to supplier verification credentials in a separate tenant while quality assurance must access quality certification credentials without visibility into financial or HR data. Furthermore, an external gearbox supplier should only access the specific wallet tenant designated for supplier interactions.

IAS enables this sophisticated access model through:

  • Group-based access control mapped to DIV wallet tenants
  • Role-based administrative permissions for provisioning and management
  • Tenant isolation, preventing unauthorized access across departments or partners

3. Centralized Security and Auditability

Without IAS, organizations would need to manage separate authentication mechanisms for DIV, adding complexity and risk. IAS provides:

  • Central enforcement of security policies (e.g. MFA, password rules, session timeouts)
  • Reduced credential sprawl and fewer attack surfaces
  • Improved visibility into authentication activity for security monitoring and audits

 

What this Series Will Build

To provide concrete context throughout this series, the following scenario is used: an automotive manufacturer implementing DIV with the following requirements:

Authentication:

  1. Employees from the manufacturing company authenticate using their corporate domain credentials
  2. Partner organizations (such as a gearbox supplier) authenticate using their own identity systems, federated through IAS
  3. Authentication is mandatory before opening any DIV wallet or accessing the DIV provisioning interface

Authorization:

  1. Define which employees can open which wallet tenants (e.g., finance employees cannot access HR credential wallets)
  2. Define which administrators from the manufacturer can provision wallet tenants
  3. Define which administrators from partner organizations (like gearbox supplier) can manage their own supplier wallets
  4. Map corporate roles to predefined DIV user roles and permissions

Outcome:

The manufacturer maintains full control over user identities, access rights, and administrative boundaries while enabling seamless integration with partner organizations’ identity systems using IAS.

 

Read more

➡️   Continue with Creating and Accessing an IAS Tenant on SAP BTP (Part 2)

➡️➡️   Jump to Connecting IAS with SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (Part 3)

 

  • Introduction to SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) and Related SSI Blog Posts 
  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Data Spaces 
  • Feature Scope Description for Decentralized Identity Verification (help page)
  • What Are Cloud Identity Services? (help page)

entry.title: Re: @sap/cds v9.6 event queue issue
entry.content:
If possible, can we verify the tokenStore handle for @SAP/cds/libx/_runtime/messaging/enterprise-messaging.js,  line 158 (handle function)

We're passing a empty tokenStore: {} object, which, make the service fetch the token every time we emit a message. Normally, this is not an issues, but in high volume of event, this cause a lot 429 error when fetch token, and slow down the whole application.

entry.title: SAC Data Action: DELETE() with IF condition not working
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I’m encountering a specific issue with a Data Action in SAP Analytics Cloud and I’m looking for some guidance.

I have a DataAction that performs a DELETE operation based on an IF condition involving two dimensions. 

When I define the MEMBERSET using the "All" node (root) of the hierarchy, the Data Action does not execute the delete as expected (it seems to ignore the scope or fail the condition). However, if I explicitly list the leaf members (ID values) of the dimension in the MEMBERSET, the script works perfectly and the data is deleted.

Is there a known limitation regarding the use of hierarchy nodes within IF conditions or DELET blocks ? How can I make the Data Action dynamic enough to include all members of a hierarchy without hardcoding every ID, while still respecting the IF logic?

Thanks in advance for your help!

Here is my code : 

MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = ("Value")
MEMBERSET [d/DIMENSION_ACCOUNT] = ("ACCOUNT1","ACCOUNT2")
MEMBERSET [d/DIMENSION_DATASOURCE] = "INPUT"

//MEMBERSET [d/DIMENSION_MATERIAL] = BASEMEMBER([d/DIMENSION_MATERIAL].[h/MATERIAL_HIER],%MAT% )
//MEMBERSET [d/DIMENSION_MATERIAL] = BASEMEMBER([d/DIMENSION_MATERIAL].[h/_MATERIAL_HIER],"[00224].[1779334]" )
MEMBERSET [d/DIMENSION_MATERIAL] = BASEMEMBER([d/DIMENSION_MATERIAL].[h/MATERIAL_HIER],"(all)" )

//MEMBERSET [d/DIMENSION_TECHNICAL_KEY] = BASEMEMBER([d/DIMENSION_TECHNICAL_KEY].[h/DIMENSION_TECHNICAL_KEY_HIER] ,"[1779332].[2002-1779332]" )
MEMBERSET [d/DIMENSION_TECHNICAL_KEY] = BASEMEMBER([d/DIMENSION_TECHNICAL_KEY].[h/DIMENSION_TECHNICAL_KEY_HIER] ,"(all)" )


IF [d/DIMENSION_MATERIAL] != [d/DIMENSION_TECHNICAL_KEY].[p/Material] THEN
   DELETE()
ENDIF

entry.title: Re: 999 – The Number of the BSEG
entry.content:
Hello obul776,

well, the FIORI app Post General Journal Entries is a manual posting triggered from FI, it's the "modern" replacement for transactions FB01 or FB50, so it's "FIN Operations". As explained above, for these manual FI postings, we do want to keep the detailed BSEGs (just as they were typed in) as "entry view" or "prima nota" document, please consider them an extended screenshot of the stuff you typed in. We don't want to summarize BSEG in this case, otherwise we would lose the "entry view" information. And, provocative question: who wants to key in manually more than 999 line items?
So again: for manual FI postings, no standard BSEG summarization will ever be performed, standard BSEG summarization is just for postings triggered from outside FI.
Now, if we're talking about the Upload General Journal Entries FIORI app (where you can upload a spreadsheet of General Journal entries), then one could argue: the "entry view" or "prima nota" is represented by the Excel file itself, the "prima nota" lies outside of the S/4HANA system, there's no need to duplicate this prima nota internally on the BSEG; moreover, uploading spreadsheets with more than 999 items is definitely a valid scenario, this is not manual work any more.
I personally maintained this opinion for many years, and a few months ago we added a button with the options "Suppress BSEGs" or "Summarize BSEGs to the maximum" to the Upload General Journal Entries app. At least in the Public Cloud edition.
In the Private Cloud edition, you could e.g. use the standard BAPIs or Journal Entry Post SOAP APIs for mass upload; here the summarization BAdi will be triggered.

Kind regards,
Stefan

entry.title: How to prepare server to use Sybase Adaptive Server Enterprise (ASE) Database for CMS
entry.content:
How to configure system to use Sybase ASE Database for CMS
Prerequisites to configure, before using Sybase ASE Database for CMS

Prerequisite before installing BI with Sybase ASE.

  • Get the database connection details from the Sybase Database Team.
  • We should have below details :
    • DB Host:Port
    • SID/Service_name
    • DB Account/password

Installing the Sybase ASE Client.

  • Download the Sybase ASE client from the software downloads.
  • Access https://me.sap.com/softwarecenter 
    • In the search box: SDK FOR SAP ASE

       

  • Select the Version and Download the same.
    • Run the installer and you will see 3 options: Typical / Full / Custom



       

    • Select Custom and choose below and Install the client


       

Setting the Environment Variable, POST Installation of Sybase ASE Client.

  • We should see under the Install Directory of Sybase ASE, file named SYBASE.bat
  • Which has information about the environment Variable.  We need to set the same.

    • Below is the sample, Assuming that the Sybase Client is has been installed under: C:\SYBASE

      set SAP_JRE8_32=C:\SYBASE\Shared\SAPJRE-8_1_102_32BIT
      set SAP_JRE8=C:\SYBASE\Shared\SAPJRE-8_1_102_64BIT
      set SAP_JRE8_64=C:\SYBASE\Shared\SAPJRE-8_1_102_64BIT
      set SYBASE_OCS=OCS-16_1
      set INCLUDE=C:\SYBASE\OCS-16_1\include;%INCLUDE%
      set LIB=C:\SYBASE\OCS-16_1\lib;%LIB%
      set PATH=C:\SYBASE\OCS-16_1\bin;C:\SYBASE\OCS-16_1\dll;C:\SYBASE\OCS-16_1\lib3p64;C:\SYBASE\OCS-16_1\lib3p;%PATH%
      set SYBASE=C:\SYBASE
      set PATH=C:\SYBASE\DataAccess\ODBC\dll;%PATH%
      set PATH=C:\SYBASE\DataAccess64\ODBC\dll;%PATH%
      set SYBROOT=C:\SYBASE
  • Once the environment variable are been set, Please restart the OS to take effect.
  • Post restart confirm if the variables have been set correctly or not.

    • Running Below command in Command Prompt will help us understand
      echo %PATH%
      echo %LIB%

POST setting the Environment Variable : Configuring the interfaces / Connectivity to the Sybase ASE Database.

  • Open the Dsedit.exe or in the start Menu Search for Open Client Directory Service Editor
  • Navigate to the Server Object > Add > 
  • In the Input Server Name: Add the SID/ Service Name that was provided by the Database Team.

     

  • On the Entry has been added, Select the Server Name and click on the last Attribute (Server Address)
  • Right Click and Modify

     

  • Choose Protocol TCP and in the Network Address Add: <HOSTNAME>,<PORT> of the Sybase ASE Database.
  • Once Done, Select any Attribute and right click on it and Select Ping Server. Or Navigate to Server Object Tab and under dropdown select Ping Server
  • You should get an message:
    Ping to <Hostname,Port> using protocol TCP
    Connection succeeded.
  • You can also check the sql.ini file. Under <Install_dir_sybase_client>/ini/sql.ini
  • There should be entries like below:

    [ServiceName/SID]
    master=TCP,Database_host,Database_port
    query=CP,Database_host,Database_port

  • SID/ Service Name would be the same as provided by Sybase ASE DB Team and the one mentioned in the Dsedit.

Checking Connectivity using isql

  • Running below command from Command prompt :
    isql -SServiceName -Uusername -Ppassword
  • If isql command is not getting recognized, it means the environment variable has not been set correctly.
